Award.AwardTitle: New Strategies for Photoinduced Carbon Monoxide Releasing Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Lisa M. Berreau of the Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry at Utah State University will develop a fundamentally new type of photoinduced carbon monoxide (CO) releasing molecules (photoCORMs). Such molecules are of significant interest for the administration of small amounts of CO that produces anti-inflammatory and antiapoptotic effects, as well as vasodilation and protection of tissues against reperfusion injury. The modular design to be pursued involves the use of a 3-hydroxy-4-pyrone unit as the CO release motif. Studies of zinc complexes wherein the structure of the pyrone and a supporting chelate ligand are systematically modified will enable elucidation of chemical factors that influence structure/physical property relationships and CO release reactivity. Complementary computational and mechanistic studies will provide insight into the reaction pathway involved in CO release and will provide guidance in the design of subsequent generations of pyrone-based CO release agents.


The new photoCORMs to be developed have the potential for use in biological and medicinal chemistry investigations, as well as applications in chemical synthesis. This project is fully integrated with the recruitment and training of undergraduate and graduate students, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences. Students will receive training in synthesis and photochemistry, and will benefit from interactions with domestic and international collaborators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon monoxide (CO) is well known as a toxic molecule that at high concentrations can induce death. A lesser-known fact is that CO is produced endogenously in humans via the breakdown of heme groups that are found in a variety of proteins, including hemoglobin. Several beneficial health effects have been identified as being associated with the production of CO. These include anti-inflammatory, anti-apoptotic, and anti-proliferative effects, as well as the promotion of vasodilation and protection of tissues against reperfusion injury. Based on this knowledge, there is considerable current interest in the development of CO release agents for biological applications. 

In the research funded by this NSF award, we have investigated the use of flavonols as visible light induced CO-releasing molecules. Flavonols are plant-derived compounds that are known for their beneficial biological properties, including antioxidant activity. We found that a simple flavonol (3-hydroxyflavone) coordinated to a biologically compatible metal (zinc) exhibits clean visible light-induced CO release. The rate of CO release can be altered through changing of the supporting structure of the zinc complexes. Coordination of the flavonol to other metal ions (e.g.,Ru(II)) produces compounds that maintain visible light-induced CO-release reactivity albeit a portion of the CO can be trapped at the metal center. 

Within this project, a new family of extended flavonols was developed that provides a rich area for future investigation. These flavonols can be structurally tuned to absorb light across the visible spectrum and exhibit variable rates of CO release depending on the flavonol structure. The extended flavonols exhibit low toxicity and are readily taken up into cells. Florescence microscopy studies have provided evidence for intracellular visible light-induced CO release. The product remaining following CO release is non-toxic. Addition of appendages to the flavonol-based CO-release unit enables sensing of other molecules in the cellular environment prior to CO release and targeting of the CO-release motif. 

Notably, coordination of the extended flavonols to zinc enabled the production of rare examples of visible-light induced solid-state CO-release compounds. These materials can be used as coatings to enable controlled CO delivery in chemical reactions requiring the use of CO as a reagent (e.g., palladium-catalyzed carbonylation).

Beyond flavonols, additional structural motifs were examined for reactivity leading to CO release. This included studies of metal/dioxygen promoted reactions involving biologically-relevant molecules with structural similarity to flavonols.  

The CO-releasing molecules developed in this project have the potential for applications in future biological and catalytic studies. The project involved the training of 9 undergraduate and 5 graduate students, of which more than 50% were female. Students gained experience in organic and inorganic syntheses, several analytical and physical methods, photochemistry, and biological investigations (e.g., toxicity assays and confocal microscopy). Six different undergraduate co-authors are listed on the published papers resulting from this research. A graduate student is a co-inventor on a patent application. Results from the project have been disseminated through journal publications and presentations at local and national meetings. The PI presented a public lecture in the USU Science Unwrapped series in 2014 describing the chemistry behind colors in nature and how colored compounds can be used in combination with light to develop new approaches for the delivery of CO. This lecture was attended by ~250 people ranging in age from small children to senior citizens. The PI is also the advisor for the USU Chemistry Club where she assists undergraduates in developing demonstrations for outreach activities to hundreds of elementary and middle school children each year.
